text.tspan: You can use the following structure as a baseline to run your UX design whiteboard exercises smoothly.

text.data-name: ・What is the ultimate purpose of the exercise? ・We ﬁnished the session and it was successful, why did we succeed?
text.tspan: What is the ultimate purpose of the exercise?
We ﬁnished the session and it was successful, why did we succeed?

text.data-name: ・Which user groups are we considering? ・Who is our Primary Persona? ・What are the behaviors this persona is currently performing? Why?
text.tspan: Which user groups are we considering?
What are the behaviors this persona is currently performing? Why?

text.data-name: ・How can we craft artifacts to validate the assumptions? ・What would be an optimal journey for the user interacting with the solution? ・What would be a happy path for users to achieve their goals?
text.tspan: How can we craft artifacts to validate the assumptions?
What would be an optimal journey for the user interacting with the solution?
What would be a happy path for users to achieve their goals?

text.data-name: ・What is the context of use? (physical space, information provided, constraints, etc.) ・What would be some device and/or technical constraints? ・What are the business objectives behind the solution?
text.tspan: What is the context of use? (physical space, information provided, constraints, etc.)
What would be some device and/or technical constraints?
What are the business objectives behind the solution?

text.data-name: ・How do we know this is the right conversation to have? ・How will we measure success?
text.tspan: How do we know this is the right conversation to have?

text.data-name: ・What assumptions are we making about the user, the business and the technology? ・If we could pick one or two assumptions to validate, which ones they would be? ・How would we validate them?
text.tspan: What assumptions are we making about the user, the business and the technology?
If we could pick one or two assumptions to validate, which ones they would be?

tspan.tspan: Spending time doing whiteboarding exercises before
committing to designing anything and getting your team
aligned with what you are pursuing at the beginning is key to
scale your product in the right direction. You can use the
following structure as a baseline to run your whiteboard
exercises smoothly.
01. The Goal -
At the top write down the ultimate goal of the
session, the objective you’re trying to achieve so it is always
visible for your team. Ask yourselves,
“What is the ultimate
purpose of doing this exercise?”
02. The User Personas -
The best next step is to bring the
user into the conversation. Ask the participants what
assumptions are being made around the target users and
decide the persona you will be focusing on.
03. Problem Space -
Within the problem space, you should
explore the context in which the behaviors are performed, the
business goals the organization is trying to accomplish while
building the product, as well as the technical constraints.
04. - Assumptions -
Insights can be written in the
assumptions section, in order for participants to make a
differentiation between what they know for a fact and what
they should research prior making important decisions.
5. Solution Space -
Discuss how the user accomplishes the
main goal, and discuss the minimum steps it might take to
reach such milestone. If you feel confident enough with the
scenario followed, you can start exploring interface
components, layouts, and interactions that should be part of
the solution in order to facilitate the experience of the users.
